awd_titl_txt: RUI: Structure and Dynamics of Negative Ions
awd_abstract_narration:
Negative ions are important in a variety of physical processes including Earth's atmosphere, stellar atmospheres and electrical discharges and plasmas. The broader impacts of this research program include contributions to the database of atomic properties, connections to other scientific fields, and the education and training of undergraduate students. Lasers will be used to measure the properties of negative ions, which are atoms and molecules that have an extra electron. Since ions are electrically charged particles, they can be manipulated to allow precise experiments. The high-precision measurements of electron binding energies in this project will be useful for modeling of chemical reactions and plasma interactions for such practical applications as semiconductor processing, lighting and plasma displays. The detailed studies of negative ions will yield insights into dynamical many-body interactions, which is a general topic of interest for a broad range of fields in physics, chemistry, materials science, and nanotechnology. The project will enhance the research and teaching infrastructure of Denison University, an undergraduate college. Students will participate in the experiments on-campus, providing important research experiences for young scientists including technical training in electronics, computers, vacuum systems, lasers, and optics. 

This project studies the interactions of photons with negative ions in a series of pulsed-laser photodetachment experiments. The extra electron in a negative ion is bound predominantly by electron correlation effects and therefore negative ions provide a fertile testing ground for state-of-the-art atomic physics calculations regarding these multi-body interactions. Complex atomic negative ions are investigated on-campus at Denison University using tunable infrared laser light to detach outer-shell electrons from negative ions produced in a sputter source. The ground and upper state photodetachment thresholds of several lanthanide and Group III negative ions (Lanthanum and Thallium) will be measured in order to determine the electron affinities and energy levels. These experiments will help explain the current strong disagreement between theoretical predictions and experimental photoelectron spectroscopy results for these interesting systems. The faculty and student researchers will investigate resonances and bound excited states in lanthanide ions including bound-bound electric-dipole transitions that exist in the negative ion of La. Additional studies will investigate inner-shell photodetachment from carbon chain negative ions and two-electron photodetachment processes. The dynamic multi-electron interactions in the photoexcitation and decay of the highly correlated cores of negative ions continue to challenge the fundamental understanding of atomic structure. The series of experiments in this project will test the latest theories describing photodetachment and negative ion structure.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the properties of negative ions, which are atoms or molecules with an extra electron. Negative ions are important in a variety of physical situations including chemical reactions, the atmospheres of planets and stars, and electrical plasmas. The primary goal of the project was to improve the understanding of how electrons interact with each other on the atomic scale (?electron correlation?) ? a very important aspect of quantum mechanics that plays a key role in the structure and stability of atoms and molecules. In experiments at Denison University, at the Advanced Light Source at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, and at the DESIREE national lab facility in Sweden, laser or synchrotron light was used to excite or detach electrons from negative ions; the light supplies a finely controlled amount of input energy to probe electron correlations within the ions. The results build the fundamental physical chemistry database, provide valuable tests of state-of-the-art theoretical atomic structure calculations, and yield key insights into dynamical many-body interaction, which is a topic of interest for a broad range of fields in physics, chemistry, materials science, and nanotechnology. Undergraduate students participated in all aspects of the research, providing significant technical training for young scientists in cutting-edge electronics, lasers, and computers, and enhancing their ability for advanced study and future careers in science, technology, and engineering.  

The Intellectual Merit of this work included both the development of new knowledge and refinement/correction of existing information on negative ions. Several types of studies were completed, including measurement of atomic electron affinities, investigations of light absorption by negative ions, and the decay dynamics of excited states of negative ions. The electron affinities of the atoms gallium and thallium (equal to the binding energies of their negative ions) were precisely measured, yielding valuable information for the physical chemistry database and resolving previous discrepancies between theory and experiment. In other experiments, the excited state structures of the negative ions of lanthanum, bismuth, and nickel were measured for the first time, providing stringent tests of detailed theoretical calculations including the complex electron correlations in these heavy elements. Finally, the radiative decay of excited states of negative ions of iridium, rhodium, and bismuth were investigated by monitoring the time evolution of their populations in an ion storage ring over periods of up to an hour to measure their lifetimes, giving information about the emission of light from excited ions. The research supported by this grant produced results that were reported to the scientific community through 7 refereed journal articles and 6 presentations at national and international conferences.        

The Broader Impacts of this proposal included important contributions to other areas of science and significant amounts of education and research training. The electron affinities we measured for gallium and thallium can be used for modeling chemical reactions involving these technologically-useful elements. The studies of lifetimes of excited negative ions give insights into the process of so-called "forbidden transitions" in atoms and ions that have important applications in such areas as highly-precise optical clocks and quantum information. In addition, the negative ion of lanthanum is a promising candidate for laser cooling, which could be used be used, for example, to sympathetically cool anti-protons; our measurements of the resonance excited state structure of this ion give useful information for assessing its feasibility for laser cooling applications. Our program provided research opportunities for two Investigators and from one to three undergraduate student researchers per summer, providing important research experiences for young scientists. The Co-PIs worked closely in the laboratory with students at Denison and also travelled with two undergraduates to the DESIREE lab in Sweden for an experimental run at the state-of-the-art international user facility. During this grant, 7 different undergraduate students have participated in our research group, completing a total of 6 summer projects and 6 academic-year projects. In addition to providing significant hands-on experimental research training opportunities, this continuing experimental program contributed positively to the overall research atmosphere on campus and to classroom activities in our physics and astronomy courses. Both Co-Investigators and many of our undergraduate students were also heavily involved with student-faculty collaborative public science outreach projects that presented physics and astronomy programs to hundreds of people each year.
